title: Providing information for young people in sexual health clinics: getting it right
abstract:
Background. The need to improve the quality and availability of information on sexual health is identified as a key element in achieving the aims set out in the National Strategy for Sexual Health and HIV. Providing information about sexual health to young people poses particular challenges because of the sensitive nature of the issues and because of the difficulties that young people may face in sourcing information and asking questions of professionals.\ud
Objective. To explore the views of young people attending\ud
sexual health services on several aspects of service\ud
delivery, including provision of information.\ud
Method. Twenty-five in-depth qualitative interviews were\ud
conducted with a purposive sample of young people\ud
attending a range of different outlets for sexual health care.\ud
Results. This research revealed important information\ud
about the ways in which the type, format, tone and design\ud
of health promotion materials and the methods used to\ud
impart information to young people has a strong impact on\ud
client satisfaction during visits to sexual health services.\ud
Conclusions. Young people vary greatly in their needs for\ud
sexual health information in terms of level, extent and\ud
manner of provision. Passive acceptance of information\ud
should not be taken to indicate tacit satisfaction with level and complexity. Written information needs to be used in conjunction with face-to-face discussion. Effective\ud
provision of sexual health information impacts notably on\ud
client satisfaction. Pitched at the right level, sexual health information has considerable potential to enhance sexual health status
